metadata.case_name: Assessee Firm v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: The assessee, a firm carrying on mining business at Udaipur with a branch at Mandal, tendered for mica mining areas pursuant to invitation under Mineral Concession Rules for Rs. 1,57,150/-, including Rs. 3,360/- for mica scrap on surface.
The lease was granted for 20 years; areas had been worked by private companies for 15 years.
Relevant assessment year 1952-53; previous year for head office ended October 30, 1951, for branch March 30, 1952.
Assessee claimed Rs. 7,857/- (1/20th of tender money) as revenue expenditure.
Income-tax Officer rejected claim as capital expenditure for value of land acquired, since mine had been worked by private companies.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed disallowance as capital expenditure for acquisition of capital asset.
Appellate Tribunal allowed Rs. 3,360/- for mica scrap on surface as revenue expenditure for stock-in-trade, but disallowed balance Rs. 1,53,800/- as capital expenditure.
Assessee claimed Rs. 3,200/- as fee for prospecting licence at Re. 1/- per acre per year.
Income-tax Officer disallowed prospecting fee under s.10(2)(xv) as initial expenditure for right to prospect mines.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner negatived claim as right to win and commercially exploit minerals.
Tribunal dismissed appeal on prospecting fee, holding it not for stock-in-trade, for initiating business, period one year.
Tribunal referred two questions to Rajasthan High Court under s.66(1): (1) Whether prospecting licence fee Rs. 3,200/- allowable as revenue? (2) Whether part of Rs. 1,53,800/- allowable as revenue?
Rajasthan High Court answered both questions in negative vide judgment dated March 28, 1968 in Income-tax Reference No. 11 of 1963.
Appeal to Supreme Court by certificate; prior appeal No. 1238/1969 dismissed without costs.
Areas offered had known mines/quarries/prospecting pits valued per Indian Mining Hand Book; applicants to visit before April 15, 1950.
Mica scrap on surface by predecessors to be removed or forfeited to Government, not to assessee.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances, the prospecting licence fee of Rs. 3,200/- is allowable as revenue expenditure?
Whether on the facts and circumstances, the appropriate part of Rs. 1,53,800/- was allowable as revenue expenditure?

petitioner_arguments.text: Rs. 1,53,800/- paid for pillars of mica standing in leased land was revenue expenditure as tender based on calculations in Indian Mining Hand Book for specific quantity of mica, assessee's stock-in-trade.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Analogies to cases like Golden Horse Shoe, tendu leaves, sand

petitioner_arguments.text: Prospecting licence fee Rs. 3,200/- is revenue as licence fee, not lease creating interest in land; under Rule 23, licensee has right to win and carry away minerals for commercial purposes, like purchase of stock-in-trade.

respondent_arguments.text: Tender amount Rs. 1,53,800/- is capital outlay for initiation of business; pillars of mica not stock-in-trade until excavated and brought to surface.
Prospecting licence fee is initial expenditure for procuring right to prospect mines, not based on quantity, for initiating business.

court_reasoning.text: Where minerals have to be won, extracted and brought to surface by mining operations, expenditure for acquiring such right is capital; where mineral already on surface, revenue for stock-in-trade.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mica pillars exposed but still embedded; assessee had to perform mining operations to extract.

court_reasoning.text: Principles from Pingle Industries apply: long-term lease acquires right to win stones/minerals in situ as capital asset, not stock-in-trade until extracted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Payment lump sum in instalments for enduring benefit.

court_reasoning.text: No contradiction in findings of ITO, AAC, Tribunal: all distinguish extracted surface minerals from embedded ones requiring extraction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Amount for right to extract mica from developed area, capital.

court_reasoning.text: Prospecting licence fee paid to initiate business by investigating/searching for minerals; not for stock-in-trade, irrespective of quantity, one-year period.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fee for right to carry out prospecting with object of conducting extraction business.

holdings.text: Expenditure of Rs. 1,53,800/- is capital as for acquiring enduring right to extract embedded mica requiring mining operations.
Prospecting licence fee Rs. 3,200/- is capital expenditure for initiating mining business.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pingle Industries Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Hyderabad
precedents_cited.relevance: Mining lease payments for right to win stones in situ are capital, not stock-in-trade until extracted.

precedents_cited.case_name: Atherton v. British Insulated and Helsby Cables Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Expenditure once and for all for enduring benefit of trade is capital.

precedents_cited.case_name: Golden Horse Shoe New Ltd. v. Thurgood, H.M. Inspector of Taxes
precedents_cited.relevance: Purchase of dumps/tailings already gotten (not to be won from soil) is revenue for stock-in-trade.

precedents_cited.case_name: Abdul Kayoom v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: No test exhaustive; each case on own facts; avoid matching cases.
Short-term contracts for collecting surface tendu leaves revenue expenditure.

precedents_cited.case_name: M.A. Jabbar v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Short lease for surface sand revenue as stock-in-trade, no digging.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kauri Timber Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Taxes
precedents_cited.relevance: Long lease for standing timber capital.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference to High Court; disallowance of expenditure not wholly laid out for business.

statutes_cited.name: Mineral Concession Rules, 1943
statutes_cited.relevance: Rights under prospecting licence; premium prohibition inapplicable to State grants.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court answered both referred questions in negative, holding both prospecting fee and tender amount (except surface scrap already allowed) as capital expenditure; appeal dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "where minerals have to be won, extracted and brought to surface by mining operations, the expenditure incurred for acquiring such a right would be of a capital nature. But where the mineral has already been gotten and is on the surface, then the expenditure incurred for obtaining the right to acquire the raw material-that is- the mineral, would be a revenue expenditure"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Empirical test for mining expenditure nature

key_quotes.text: "Each case depends on its own facts, and a close similarity between one case and another is not enough, because even a single significant detail may alter the entire aspect."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Caution against analogical matching of cases (quoting Abdul Kayoom)

key_quotes.text: "the fee was paid to obtain a licence to carryout, investigate, search and find the mineral with the object of conducting the business of extracting ore from the earth."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Reason for prospecting fee being capital
